title: Stones, Altar, and Curses
shortSummary: Deuteronomy 27 records Moses’ instructions to the Israelites as they prepare to enter the Promised Land. It details the setting up of stones inscribed with the law, the building of an altar on Mount Ebal, and the pronouncement of blessings and curses to affirm obedience to God’s commandments. This chapter emphasizes covenant faithfulness and the serious consequences of disobedience.
timeline: c. 1406 BC - Israel prepares to enter the Promised Land after the Exodus

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The leader and prophet who commands Israel to obey God's law and instructs them on covenant ceremonies.

keyCharacters.name: The Elders of Israel
keyCharacters.description: Leaders who assist Moses in commanding the people and overseeing the covenant renewal.

keyCharacters.name: The Levites
keyCharacters.description: The priestly tribe responsible for speaking the curses aloud to the people as part of the covenant ceremony.

definitions.definition: A type of plaster or mortar used to cover and smooth the stones on which the law was written.
An altar built from uncut stones, symbolizing purity and that no tools of iron (representing war or corruption) were used.
A covenant practice where blessings are pronounced on obedience and curses on disobedience to God's law.
A boundary marker defining property lines, which was protected by law to prevent injustice.

outline.heading: Command to Obey and Prepare Stones
outline.description: Moses commands the people to obey God's law and instructs them to set up large stones plastered and inscribed with the law upon entering the land, establishing a visible reminder of their covenant obligations.

outline.heading: Building the Altar on Mount Ebal
outline.description: The Israelites are to build an altar of uncut stones on Mount Ebal to offer burnt and peace offerings, symbolizing worship and fellowship with God.

outline.heading: Declaration of Covenant Identity
outline.description: Moses and the Levites declare that Israel has become God's people and must therefore obey His commandments fully.

outline.heading: Division of Tribes for Blessing and Cursing
outline.description: The tribes are divided between Mount Gerizim for blessing and Mount Ebal for cursing, signifying the dual outcomes of obedience or disobedience.

outline.heading: Pronouncement of the Curses
outline.description: The Levites loudly proclaim a series of curses on specific sins that violate God's covenant, with the people responding 'Amen' to affirm their agreement and understanding of the consequences.

application: Regularly remind yourself of God’s commands by reading and meditating on Scripture to keep His law clearly before you.
Build your life on the uncut, pure foundation of God’s Word, avoiding compromise or ‘cutting corners’ in obedience.
Recognize the blessings that come from obedience and the serious consequences of sin, motivating faithful living.
Participate actively in corporate worship and covenant renewal, affirming your identity as God’s people.

keyVerses.text: And Moses and the priests the Levites spake unto all Israel, saying, Take heed, and hearken, O Israel; this day thou art become the people of the LORD thy God.
keyVerses.significance: This verse marks the covenantal identity of Israel as God’s chosen people, foundational for their obedience.

keyVerses.text: Cursed be he that confirmeth not all the words of this law to do them. And all the people shall say, Amen.
keyVerses.significance: This verse emphasizes the necessity of full obedience to God’s law, warning against partial or selective adherence.

keyVerses.text: And there shalt thou build an altar unto the LORD thy God, an altar of stones: thou shalt not lift up any iron tool upon them.
keyVerses.significance: This instruction highlights the holiness and purity required in worship, forbidding tools associated with violence or defilement.
